text: Induction of tyrosine phosphorylation and T-cell activation by vanadate peroxide , an inhibitor of protein tyrosine phosphatases .
Rapid tyrosine phosphorylation of key cellular proteins is a crucial event in the transduction of activation signals to T-lymphocytes .

The regulatory role of protein tyrosine phosphatases ( PTPases ) in this process was explored by studying the effects of a powerful PTPase inhibitor , vanadate peroxide ( pervanadate ) , on the activation cascade of Jurkat human leukaemic T-cells .

Pervanadate induced activation of the tyrosine kinases <extra_id_0> lck <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> fyn <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( 4 - and 3-fold respectively ) and a dramatic increase in tyrosine phosphorylation of cellular proteins , notably <extra_id_0> phospholipase C gamma 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: After this event , we observed a rise in intracellular Ca2+ concentration , corresponding to an influx .

This effect required surface expression of the <extra_id_0> CD45 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> PTPase and was not observed in <extra_id_0> CD45 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient variants of Jurkat cells .

In the <extra_id_0> CD45 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - negative variant , the effect of pervanadate on tyrosine phosphorylation was globally decreased and some phosphorylated substrates were specifically missing .

Pervanadate also stimulated transcription of the <extra_id_0> c-fos <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene and accumulation of its mRNA as well as several other hallmarks of T-lymphocyte activation such as surface expression of the <extra_id_0> CD69 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antigen and the <extra_id_0> interleukin 2 receptor alpha-chain <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> CD25 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) .

text: Pervanadate synergized with signals delivered by T-cell antigen receptor engagement or by a phorbol ester to induce <extra_id_0> interleukin 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production .
Pervanadate activated NF-kappa B , as shown by an increase in DNA - binding activity of this transcription factor .
We thus conclude that PTPases play a crucial role in the negative regulation of signal transduction culminating in T-lymphocyte activation .
Moreover , induction of tyrosine phosphorylation appears sufficient per se to initiate a complete activation programme .
